title: 110_hr3059
content: Increased average fuel economy standards. The amendment to Section 32902 of title 49, United States Code increases the average fuel economy standard for non-passenger automobiles to 27.5 miles per gallon for model year 2022 and subsequent years. Regulations for passenger automobiles are also prescribed by the Secretary at least 18 months before each model year. The Secretary prescribes average fuel economy standards for passenger automobiles based on vehicle attributes. The standard for model year 2022 and beyond must be at least 35 miles per gallon. Additionally, an alternative minimum standard is provided for passenger automobiles based on vehicle attributes. The alternative minimum standard for domestically manufactured passenger automobiles is set at either 27.5 miles per gallon or 92 percent of the average fuel economy projected by the Secretary for all manufacturers in that model year. This standard applies only if the manufacturer cannot comply with the average fuel economy standard based on vehicle attributes. The manufacturer can choose to comply with a less stringent average fuel economy standard during a transition period for the first 3 model years. The amendments made by this section will take effect upon the enactment of the Act, with existing standards for passenger automobiles remaining in effect until a new standard is established. The amendments to Chapter 329 of title 49, United States Code, include defining a 'non-passenger automobile' and making technical changes to subsections regarding fuel economy standards. The amendments in Chapter 329 of title 49, United States Code involve changes to subsections related to fuel economy standards, including redefining a 'non-passenger automobile' and making technical adjustments to various sections. The amendments in Chapter 329 of title 49, United States Code involve changes to fuel economy standards, including redefining a 'non-passenger automobile' and making technical adjustments to various sections. Additionally, there is a provision for credit transferring within a manufacturer's fleet. The Secretary of Transportation will establish a credit transferring program for manufacturers to apply excess fuel economy credits within their fleet to non-compliant categories. Transferred credits can be used in the same model years they were earned, with a maximum increase of 1.0 mile per gallon. Transfers to specific categories are limited based on the manufacturer's fleet fuel economy level. The Secretary of Transportation will establish a credit transferring program for manufacturers to apply excess fuel economy credits within their fleet to non-compliant categories. Transferred credits can only be used if earned in model year 2010 or later. The terms 'fleet' and 'compliance category of automobiles' are defined for clarity. The Secretary of Transportation will partner with industry groups to create a public education campaign on fuel conservation for drivers. The campaign will use various methods to reach a wide audience and the Secretary will provide up to 50% of the campaign's cost, with the option to accept private funds. Appropriations will be made as needed for this program.
